head.title: Electronic Structure of Multicomponent Organic Molecular Materials: Evaluation of Range-Separated Hybrid Functionals | Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation

meta.content: Electronic Structure of Multicomponent Organic Molecular Materials: Evaluation of Range-Separated Hybrid Functionals

Range-separated hybrid (RSH) functionals have become a tool of choice to study the intra- and inter-molecular electronic states in organic materials. These functionals provide the most accurate descriptions of the electronic structure when the range-separation parameter is optimally tuned (OT). However, since the range-separation parameter is molecule dependent, this approach faces consistency issues when applied to the multicomponent systems typically found in the active layers of organic solar cells or organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs). Here, we investigate the performance of four common RSH functionals in the description of the excited states of three molecular compounds used as components of the active layer in a hyperfluorescence OLED device. Our results indicate that the excited-state energies of the investigated molecules show a very weak dependence on the range-separation parameter value when they are evaluated by means of a screened version of RSH functionals. In this instance, the excited states of all three molecular compounds can be derived accurately and consistently with the exact same functional.

div.p:
Range-separated hybrid (RSH) functionals have become a tool of choice to study the
intra-
and
inter
-molecular electronic states in organic materials. These functionals provide the most accurate descriptions of the electronic structure when the range-separation parameter is optimally tuned (OT). However, since the range-separation parameter is molecule dependent, this approach faces consistency issues when applied to the multicomponent systems typically found in the active layers of organic solar cells or organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs). Here, we investigate the performance of four common RSH functionals in the description of the excited states of three molecular compounds used as components of the active layer in a hyperfluorescence OLED device. Our results indicate that the excited-state energies of the investigated molecules show a very weak dependence on the range-separation parameter value when they are evaluated by means of a screened version of RSH functionals. In this instance, the excited states of all three molecular compounds can be derived accurately and consistently with the exact same functional.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The active layers in organic electronic devices usually consist of blends containing two or more molecular and/or polymeric components. In organic solar cells, two components are usually present, an electron-donor material and an electron-acceptor material, in either a bilayer or a bulk-heterojunction architecture.
(1−3)
Similarly, in organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), the active layers generally contain two components, a host and a guest (dopant) emitter. However, in the case of hyperfluorescence OLEDs,
(4−6)
the matrix hosts both thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) molecules and highly fluorescent emitters. The role of the TADF molecules
(7−9)
is to convert the electrically generated triplet excitons into singlet excitons in order to increase the internal quantum efficiency for electroluminescence significantly beyond the spin statistical limit of 25%. The singlet excitons are then energy transferred to the fluorescent molecules, which are selected to achieve high quantum yield and high color purity.

On the theory side, the accurate determination of the electronic processes that take place in these organic electronic devices requires a quantum mechanical methodology that can adequately describe both the
intra
-molecular and
inter
-molecular excited states in the active layers. Given the large size of the molecules or polymer repeat units of interest, post-Hartree–Fock (HF) quantum mechanical techniques often turn out to be too computationally expensive. Thus, the electronic states in these materials are usually evaluated with density functional theory (DFT) methodologies. Given that many of the organic materials of choice are made of both electronic-rich and electron-poor moieties, their lowest
intra
-molecular and
inter
-molecular excitations generally display a strong charge-transfer (CT) character. Among the DFT functionals, range-separated hybrids (RSH) have been found to provide the most satisfactory description of the CT states
(10−14)
and have thus become the tool of choice to study the excited states of such organic electronic materials.

In the case of multicomponent systems, it is important to be able to identify an RSH functional that could adequately describe the intramolecular electronic states of
all
the compounds present in the active layer. In order to illustrate this issue, we have chosen to focus on the excited states of a host/double-dopant OLED active layer, consisting of 3,3-di(9
H
-carbazol-9-yl)biphenyl (mCBP, host material), 2,4,5,6-tetra(9
H
-carbazol-9-yl)isophthalonitrile (4CzIPN, TADF dopant molecule), and 2,8-di-
tert
-butyl-5,11-bis(4-
tert
-butylphenyl)-6,12-diphenyltetracene (TBRb, fluorescent emitter); see the chemical structures in
Figure
1
. We note that an active layer based on such components was recently exploited in highly efficient and stable hyperfluorescence OLEDs.
(5)
Here, we investigate the performance of four common RSH approaches in describing the lowest triplet and singlet states of TBRb, 4CzIPN, and mCBP. The results are compared to available experimental data.

div.p: Figure 1. Chemical structures of (a) mCBP, (b) 4CzIPN, and (c) TBRb.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In the framework of RSH functionals,
(15)
the interelectron Coulomb potential is partitioned into two spatial domains, a short-range domain and a long-range domain. This partition is usually performed by employing the error function erf(ω
r
):
(1)
Here,
r
denotes the electron–electron distance, and ω is the range-separation parameter. The first and second terms on the right-hand side correspond to the long-range and short-range domains, respectively. The long-range part uses exact HF exchange, which provides for the correct 1/
r
asymptotic behavior, while the short-range part is usually based on a semilocal functional. For isolated systems, it has been shown that RSH functionals provide the most accurate descriptions of the electronic structure when the range-separation parameter is “optimally tuned” (OT-RSH approach) by relying on a nonempirical, physically sound optimization condition.
(13,16)
In all the cases considered here, the range-separation parameter ω was tuned by minimizing the target function
J
OT
(ω):
(16)
(2)
where
E
HOMO
and
E
LUMO
are the energies of the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) and IP and EA indicate the vertical first ionization potential and electron affinity of the molecule, respectively. The optimal tuning of ω was performed both for an isolated molecule (in vacuum)
(16,17)
and for a molecule imbedded in a dielectric medium.
(18−21)

A simple way to incorporate the dielectric screening effect due to the solid-state medium or solvent molecules is to combine the DFT calculations with the polarizable continuum model (PCM). Here, these calculations were performed using (a) the equilibrium solvation model (where the electronic and nuclear motions of the solvent molecules are in equilibrium with the electronic density of the solute) and (b) the nonequilibrium solvation model (where the solvent molecules are kept frozen in the equilibrium configuration for the initial solute density).
(22,23)
The sets of tuned ω values obtained via the tuning procedures based on (i) OT-RSH calculations performed in vacuum (OT-RSH/vac), (ii) using the equilibrium PCM (OT-RSH/pcm) scheme, or (iii) the nonequilibrium PCM (OT-RSH/nepcm) scheme are denoted as ω
vac
, ω
pcm
, and ω
nepcm
, respectively.

The fourth DFT approach we considered is based on a screened range-separated hybrid (SRSH) functional. Here, the partition of the Coulomb interaction involves two additional parameters α and β with respect to
eq 1
:
(24)
(3)
The long-range potential evolves as (α + β)/
r
, with the amount of long-range HF exchange controlled by adjusting the [α + β] value (we note that, in the RSH functionals, the potential evolves simply as 1/
r
since it corresponds to taking effectively (α + β) as equal to 1). The effect of the medium in the SRSH approach is achieved by setting α + β = 1/ε, where ε is the medium dielectric constant.
(25)
Thus, this approach has the formal advantage that it can account for the dielectric screening while using the same range-separation parameter ω
vac
as the one tuned for the calculations on the isolated molecules (we refer to this functional as OT-SRSH). We note that the OT-SRSH approach was recently found to capture correctly the charge-transfer state energies in donor–acceptor complexes as well as the fundamental gaps and optical spectra of molecular solids.
(21,26−28)

The calculations were performed using the LC-ωhPBE functional:
(21)
(4)
Here, SR and LR denote the short- and long-range terms; HF_X is the Hartree–Fock exchange; and PBE_X and PBE_C are the PBE exchange and correlation terms. The α value in
eq 4
was set to 0.2 (20% HF exchange), and the 6-31G** basis set was used throughout. In the case of OT-RSH calculations, the parameter β in
eq 4
was set to 0.8 to satisfy the (α + β) = 1 condition, while the OT-SRSH calculations were performed using β = (1/ε) – 0.2. The optimization of the molecular geometries in the ground state of the neutral and charged configurations were performed with each of the four OT-RSH and OT-SRSH functionals. The OT-RSH/pcm, OT-RSH/nepcm, and OT-SRSH calculations were carried out using a dielectric constant ε = 3 (which is a characteristic value for organic electronic materials);
(29,30)
additional SRSH-based calculations were carried out as a function of ε. For the sake of comparison, electronic-structure calculations were also performed on TBRb, 4CzIPN, and mCBP using the PBE0 functional.
(31)
The vertical and adiabatic excited-state energies and the transition dipole moments were determined by means of time-dependent DFT (TDDFT) calculations based on the Tamm-Dancoff approximation (TDA).
(32)
In order to better visualize the nature of the excited states, we also evaluated the natural transition orbitals (NTOs) for both triplet and singlet excited states. In the case of 4CzIPN and mCBP, each excited state was further characterized by calculating its CT and local-excitation (LE) contributions. This was performed by computing the atomic dipole moment-corrected Hirschfeld (ADCH)
(33)
charges of the donor and acceptor molecular fragments as implemented in the Multiwfn program.
(34)
In these calculations, the carbazole units are assigned as donor fragments and the isophthalonitrile (IPN) and biphenyl units as acceptor fragments. The DFT calculations were carried out with the Gaussian16 package.
(35)

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The optimally tuned values of the range-separation parameters ω for the three molecules are listed in
Table
1
. The ω
pcm
values are about six times smaller than the ω
vac
values, with the ω
nepcm
values being halfway between the ω
vac
and ω
pcm
values. Interestingly, the tuned ω values obtained for 4CzIPN and TBRb are very similar but up to 50% smaller than those for mCBP, regardless of the computational methodology. The difference among the ω values is largest when using the RSH/vac approach and decreases gradually in going to RSH/nepcm and then RSH/pcm.

Table 1. Optimally Tuned ω Values of mCBP, 4CzIPN, and TBRb, Obtained from OT-RSH/vac, OT-RSH/pcm, and OT-RSH/nepcm Calculations Performed at the LC-ωhPBE/6-31G** Level
a

div.p:
The ω units are in bohr
–1
.

div.div:
First, we consider the electronic structure of TBRb. We note that this molecule has been used as a highly efficient yellow emitter in OLED devices.
(36)
In all cases, the lowest singlet and triplet states correspond to conventional molecular backbone transitions (to which we refer here as local excitations, LE) with the related hole and electron NTOs located on the rubrene core (see
Figure S1
in the SI). The TDDFT results for the S
1
and T
1
energies are collected in
Table
2
. As seen from
Table
2
, the energies of both S
1
and T
1
states are only slightly affected by the choice of the DFT functional: The S
1
adiabatic energies vary in a range from 2.32 eV (OT-RSH/vac) to 2.16 eV (OT-RSH/pcm). The OT-RSH/nepcm and OT-SRSH energies are very similar and only slightly larger than those derived at the OT-RSH/pcm level. The calculated adiabatic S
1
energies agree very well with the 2.25 eV value estimated from the experimental emission and absorption spectra.
(4,5)
Singlet fission and triplet fusion data suggest that the lowest triplet state energy in TBRb and the parent rubrene molecule should be very close to half that of S
1
.
(37,38)
Our DFT results for the T
1
energy are in line with this expectation.

Table 2. Vertical and Adiabatic (*) Singlet and Triplet Energies and Singlet–Triplet Energy Gaps in TBRb, Obtained from OT-RSH/vac, OT-RSH/pcm, OT-RSH/nepcm, and OT-SRSH Calculations
a

div.p: All energies are given in eV.

div.div:
Next, we discuss the results derived for 4CzIPN; see
Table
3
. We note that the excited states of this system have been previously studied at several DFT levels,
(39−43)
including the OT-RSH/vac approach.
(39,42)
The NTOs, irrespective of the functional used, indicate that the S
1
and T
1
states both have a dominant (about 80%) charge-transfer (CT) character (see
Figure S2
and
Table S1
); the electron wave functions are mainly localized on the acceptor IPN unit while the hole wave functions are delocalized over the entire molecule. As in the case of TBRb, the largest and smallest transition energies for both the S
1
and the T
1
states are obtained at the OT-RSH/vac and OT-RSH/pcm levels, respectively; again, the OT-RSH/nepcm and OT-SRSH estimates are very similar and only slightly larger than those derived using the OT-RSH/pcm approach. However, the variance (about 0.4 eV) in the estimated energies across the four methods is twice as large as in TBRb.

Table 3. Vertical and Adiabatic (*) Singlet and Triplet Energies and Singlet–Triplet Energy Gaps in 4CzIPN, Obtained by Means of OT-RSH/vac, OT-RSH/pcm, OT-RSH/nepcm, and OT-SRSH Calculations
a

div.p: All energies are given in eV.

div.div:
The experimental adiabatic S
1
energy, obtained from the crossing point of the emission and absorption spectra measured in toluene, is about 2.63 eV.
(41,44,45)
In the literature, the adiabatic energies are also frequently estimated from the onset of the fluorescence and phosphorescence spectra; in toluene, this approach yields S
1
and T
1
energies of 2.71 and 2.67 eV, respectively, which results in a very small Δ
E
ST
value of 4 meV.
(41,44,45)
We note that according to both calculations and experiment the lowest local-excitation (LE) state of 4CzIPN appears about 0.5 eV above the S
1
state.
(44)

As seen from
Table
3
, here, the OT-RSH/vac energies for both triplet and singlet states compare very well with the experimental values. On the other hand, the estimates obtained with the three approaches that account for the interaction with the environment are somewhat (0.3 eV) smaller than the experimental energies. However, these calculations were carried out with a dielectric constant of 3, while the measurements were performed in toluene for which ε = 2.38. In order to further characterize the effect of the environment on the excitation energies, the lowest excited-state energies were calculated with the OT-SRSH approach as a function of ε. As shown in
Figure
2
, the TBRb energies are hardly affected by the implicit interaction with the surrounding medium. In contrast, the S
1
and T
1
energies of 4CzIPN show a linear dependence as a function of 1/ε, as was previously found for intermolecular CT states.
(21)
A decrease in the CT energy of 4CzIPN in going to a more polar solvent has also been observed experimentally.
(46,47)
Here, an increase in ε from 2 to 3 results in a red shift of the calculated S
1
and T
1
energies by 0.1 eV. Taking this effect into account and also the fact that the lowest experimental absorption band in 4CzIPN contains, in addition to S
1
, contributions from several other low-lying CT states, it can be concluded that the OT-RSH/pcm, OT-RSH/nepcm, and especially OT-SRSH approaches provide a very good description of the 4CzIPN excited states.

div.p: Figure 2. Dependence of the singlet and triplet energies of TBRb (black), 4CzIPN (blue), and mCBP (red) as a function of 1/ε based on OT-RSH/vac optimized geometries. The results obtained at the SRSH LC-ωhPBE/6-31G** level of theory are shown with solid lines while the PBE0/6-31G** results are shown with dashed and dotted lines.

div.div:
Finally, we turn to the discussion of the excited states of the host mCBP molecule. The electronic structure of this molecule is more complex than those of TBRb and 4CzIPN. The meta-linkage of the carbazole units to the biphenyl bridge results in a weak interaction between the two carbazole units. As a result, there appears two nearly degenerate carbazole-based LE states and two nearly degenerate CT states. Moreover, the calculations show that the energies of these CT and LE states are close. These features lead to the fact that the nature of the lowest excited state depends on the functional. The energies of the lowest three triplet and singlet states are listed in
Table
4
, while the related NTOs are shown in
Figures
3
and
4
. The OT-RSH/vac calculations give the lowest two singlet states as carbazole-based (LE) states, followed by two CT states; this ordering of the CT and LE states becomes inverted when OT-RSH/pcm, OT-RSH/nepcm, and OT-SRSH calculations are performed (see
Figure
3
). The situation is similar in the case of the lowest triplet states except that here there occurs competition between carbazole- and biphenyl-based states (see
Figure
4
): the OT-RSH/vac calculations depict T
1
and T
2
as carbazole-based states followed by a biphenyl-based T
3
state that has some CT contribution. Again, the ordering of these states is inverted with the other functionals. As
Figure
2
had shown, the natures of the lowest excited singlet and triplet states are very sensitive to the dielectric medium; in the case of the singlet state, a switch of the CT and LE state energies is observed around ε = 1.2.

Table 4. Vertical and Adiabatic (*) Singlet and Triplet Energies and Singlet–Triplet Energy Gaps in mCBP, Obtained by Means of OT-RSH/vac, OT-RSH/pcm, OT-RSH/nepcm, and OT-SRSH Calculations
a

div.p: The oscillator strengths for the singlet excited states are given in parentheses. All energies are in eV.

Figure 3. Hole and electron natural transition orbitals (NTOs) in the S
1
, S
2
, and S
3
states of mCBP, obtained by means of OT-RSH/vac, OT-RSH/pcm, OT-RSH/nepcm, and OT-SRSH calculations.

Figure 4. Hole and electron natural transition orbitals (NTOs) in the T
1
, T
2
, and T
3
states of mCBP, obtained by means of OT-RSH/vac, OT-RSH/pcm, OT-RSH/nepcm, and OT-SRSH calculations.

div.div:
The experimental adiabatic S
1
energies obtained from the emission and absorption spectra measured in hexane and a neat film are about 3.65 and 3.55 eV, respectively.
(48)
These energies are in very good agreement with the 3.4 eV value estimated with the OT-RSH/nepcm and OT-SRSH approaches. However, while the calculations indicate that S
1
corresponds to a CT state with a very small transition dipole moment, the fluorescence spectra observed in hexane and a neat film very much resemble the fluorescence spectrum of carbazole; as mentioned above, the OT-RSH/vac calculations predict S
1
to be carbazole-based. It should be borne in mind, however, that emission from an LE state can be still observed even if this state is located above a nonemissive CT state as long as these two states are separated by a small activation barrier. Such a situation has been observed, for instance, in systems formed by covalently bridging two monomers.
(49,50)

In the case of the T
1
state, the mCBP phosphorescence spectrum resembles that of biphenyl.
(48)
This result is well reproduced by the OT-RSH/pcm, OT-RSH/nepcm, and OT-SRSH calculations, which show that T
1
is mainly localized on the biphenyl core with a ca. 35–40% CT contribution. These three approaches give similar energies for the T
1
state, about 2.90–2.94 eV (adiabatic energies), which are in very good agreement with the value of 2.95 eV estimated from the onset of the phosphorescence spectrum.
(48)

As for the other two molecules, we note a great similarity in mCBP between the results obtained by means of OT-RSH/nepcm and OT-SRSH calculations. Overall, our results point out that, in the case of systems like mCBP where there exists quasi-degeneracy between different electronic states that can be impacted by the environment, the choice of the DFT functional must be made very carefully. If possible, the results of the calculations should be calibrated against experimental data.

It is also instructive to compare the SRSH results with those obtained using the (default) PBE0 functional. As seen from
Figure
2
, SRSH and PBE0 provide similar results for the local excited states across the whole range of dielectric constant values. However, in the case of singlet CT states, the overall dependence of the PBE0 singlet CT energies as a function of dielectric constant is physically erroneous as it would suggest that the CT energies increase with an increase in ε. As a result, the SRSH and PBE0 results for the singlet CT states are comparable only for a dielectric constant up to about 2 and linearly deviate from each other beyond that value.

Overall, our results underline that, in the case of multicomponent systems where the low energy states of some components might have a charge-transfer character, the computational approach has to account correctly for medium/environment effects. Based on the present and earlier studies,
(13,21)
it appears preferable to rely on the SRSH functional. However, when doing so, the common procedure, as discussed in the
Computational Methodology
section, is to use for the OT-SRSH approach the range-separation parameter ω
vac
tuned at the OT-RSH/vac level. The issue then, as seen from
Table
1
, is that ω
vac
for mCBP is about 50% larger than those optimized for 4CzIPN and TBRb, which puts into question the possible use of a single ω parameter in order to provide a reasonable description of all three molecules.

To gain a better understanding of the problem, we computed the excited states of the three molecules with the SRSH functional as a function of the range-separation parameters obtained in the ε = 1 and ε = 3 cases; see
Figure
5
. For ε = 1, the energies show a strong dependence on ω, in particular those of the CT states. In contrast, for ε = 3, this dependence is significantly reduced as the relative change in the energies amounts to only about 2% when ω varies over the range 0.10–0.15 bohr
–1
, which corresponds to the range spanned by the ω
vac
values of the three molecules (this trend is further validated by the results obtained for the CT states calculated for three additional molecules: 2CzPN, 5CzBN, and 3Cz2DPhCzBN; see
Figure S3
). This result can be understood on the basis that SRSH functionals exhibit lesser variations at short and intermediate distances as a function of ω as ε departs from 1. It is interesting to note that the LC-ωhPBE functional including 20% HF exchange (α = 0.2) shows no dependence on ω when ε approaches 5. Thus, our results highlight that a good description of the excited states of TBRb, 4CzIPN, and mCBP can be obtained simultaneously by using an ω value in the range of 0.10–0.15 bohr
–1
.

div.p:
Figure 5. Dependence of the calculated singlet energies of mCBP (red), 4CzIPN (blue), and TBRb (black) based on optimized geometries using ω
gas
as a function of ω at the SRSH LC-ωhPBE/6-31G** level with (a) ε = 1 and (b) ε = 3. Solid and dashed lines correspond to calculated and experimental results, respectively. The stars (★) point to the ω values tuned in vacuum.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div: We have evaluated the performance of four common range-separated hybrid (RSH) functionals to describe the excited-state properties of three molecules, TBRb, 4CzIPN, and mCBP, used as active components in hyperfluorescence-OLED applications. Our results show that, in the case of the fluorescent emitter TBRb, where the lowest singlet and triplet states are characterized as local excitations (LE states), the excitation energies are insensitive to the details of the computational methodology. On the other hand, the description of the excited states of 4CzIPN and mCBP, due to their charge-transfer (CT) character, has a marked dependence on the computational approach.

In order to account for the impact of the medium, we used three approaches: a screened RSH functional using the range-separated parameter optimized for an isolated molecule and two RSH functionals for which the range-separated parameters were optimized by taking the interaction with the medium into account via either equilibrium or nonequilibrium solvation models. For all systems, we found that the results from OT-SRSH calculations are very close to those obtained with the RSH functional when ω is optimally tuned within a nonequilibrium solvation model.

Finally, the most practical outcome of our study is that we have shown that the lowest excited states derived by means of the SRSH functional show a very moderate dependence on the choice of the range-separation parameter. Therefore, we propose that a reliable, consistent description of the excited states in multicomponent systems, such as those consisting of TBRb, 4CzIPN, and mCBP molecular materials, can be obtained by relying on a SRSH functional with the same ω for all three molecules.

Efficient photodiodes from interpenetrating polymer networks
Halls, J. J. M.; Walsh, C. A.; Greenham, N. C.; Marseglia, E. A.; Friend, R. H.; Moratti, S. C.; Holmes, A. B.

The photovoltaic effect involves the prodn. of electrons and holes in a semiconductor device under illumination, and their subsequent collection at opposite electrodes. In many inorg. semiconductors, photon absorption produces free electrons and holes directly. But in mol. semiconductors, absorption creates electron-hold pairs (excitons) which are bound at room temp., so that charge collection requires their dissocn. Exciton dissocn. is known to be efficient at interfaces between materials with different electron affinities and ionization potentials, where the electron is accepted by the material with larger electron affinity and the hole by the material with lower ionization potential. A two-layer diode structure can thus be used, in which excitons generated in either layer diffuse towards the interface between the layers. However, the exciton diffusion range is typically at least a factor of 10 smaller than the optical absorption depth, thus limiting the efficiency of charge collection. Here, the authors show that the interpenetrating network formed from a phase-segregated mixt. of two semiconducting polymers provides both the spatially distributed interfaces necessary for efficient charge photogeneration, and the means for sep. collecting the electrons and holes. Devices using thin films of these polymer mixts. show promise for large-area photodetectors.

A thin-film, 2-layer org. photovoltaic cell was fabricated from Cu phthalocyanine [147-14-8] and a perylene tetracarboxylic deriv. A power conversion efficiency of ∼1% was achieved under simulated air-mass-2 illumination. A novel feature of the device is that the charge-generation efficiency is relatively independent of the bias voltage, resulting in cells with fill factor values of 0.65. The interface between the 2 org. materials, rather than the electrode/org. contacts, is crucial in detg. the photovoltaic properties of the cell.

The carrier collection efficiency (ηc) and energy conversion efficiency (ηe) of polymer photovoltaic cells were improved by blending of the semiconducting polymer with C60 or its functionalized derivs. Composite films of poly(2-methoxy-5-(2'-ethyl-hexyloxy)-1,4-phenylene vinylene) (MEH-PPV) and fullerenes exhibit ηc of about 29 percent of electrons per photon and ηe of about 2.9 percent, efficiencies that are better by more than two orders of magnitude than those that have been achieved with devices made with pure MEH-PPV. The efficient charge sepn. results from photoinduced electron transfer from the MEH-PPV (as donor) to C60 (as acceptor); the high collection efficiency results from a bi-continuous network of internal donor-acceptor heterojunctions.

Fluorescence-based org. light-emitting diodes have continued to attract interest because of their long operational lifetimes, high color purity of electroluminescence and potential to be manufd. at low cost in next-generation full-color display and lighting applications. In fluorescent mols., however, the exciton prodn. efficiency is limited to 25% due to the deactivation of triplet excitons. Here we report fluorescence-based org. light-emitting diodes that realize external quantum efficiencies as high as 13.4-18% for blue, green, yellow and red emission, indicating that the exciton prodn. efficiency reached nearly 100%. The high performance is enabled by utilization of thermally activated delayed fluorescence mols. as assistant dopants that permit efficient transfer of all elec. generated singlet and triplet excitons from the assistant dopants to the fluorescent emitters. Org. light-emitting diodes employing this exciton harvesting process provide freedom for the selection of emitters from a wide variety of conventional fluorescent mols.

Recently, triplet harvesting via a thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) process has been established as a realistic route for obtaining ultimate internal electroluminescence (EL) quantum efficiency in org. light-emitting diodes (OLEDs). However, the possibility that the rather long transient lifetime of the triplet excited states would reduce operational stability due to an increased chance for unwarranted chem. reactions has been a concern. Herein, we demonstrate dual enhancement of EL efficiency and operational stability in OLEDs by employing a TADF mol. as an assistant dopant and a fluorescent mol. as an end emitter. The proper combination of assistant dopant and emitter mols. realized a "one-way" rapid Forster energy transfer of singlet excitons from TADF mols. to fluorescent emitters, reducing the no. of cycles of intersystem crossing (ISC) and reverse ISC in the TADF mols. and resulting in a significant enhancement of operational stability compared to OLEDs with a TADF mol. as the end emitter. In addn., we found that the presence of this rapid energy transfer significantly suppresses singlet-triplet annihilation. Using this finely-tuned rapid triplet-exciton upconversion scheme, OLED performance and lifetime was greatly improved.

A thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) sensitizer plays a key role in harvesting 100% excitons and transferring energy in TADF-assisted fluorescent org. light-emitting diodes (TAF-OLEDs). Despite its important roles, there have been few studies investigating how a TADF sensitizer affects the overall device performance and resonance energy transfer (RET) process in TAF-OLEDs. In this study, we investigate the effects of different parameters of sensitizers, i.e., spectra overlap and radiative const. (kr) on the device performances and RET process by developing two red emitters (OTPA-BT-CN and POZ-BT-CN) and choosing two TADF materials with similar photoluminescence spectra (4CzIPN and OSTFB). Mechanism studies reveal that kr of the sensitizer, rather than the overlap of sensitizer and fluorescent emitter, plays a more significant role in TAF-OLEDs. As a result, the device with higher kr of the sensitizer achieves a max. external quantum efficiency (EQE) of 12.4% with an emission peak of 612 nm, which is higher by 2.0-fold compared with that of a 4CzIPN-based device (6.3%).

The inherent flexibility afforded by mol. design has accelerated the development of a wide variety of org. semiconductors over the past 2 decades. In particular, great advances were made in the development of materials for org. light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), from early devices based on fluorescent mols. to those using phosphorescent mols. In OLEDs, elec. injected charge carriers recombine to form singlet and triplet excitons in a 1:3 ratio; the use of phosphorescent metal-org. complexes exploits the normally nonradiative triplet excitons and so enhances the overall electroluminescence efficiency. Here the authors report a class of metal-free org. electroluminescent mols. in which the energy gap between the singlet and triplet excited states is minimized by design, thereby promoting highly efficient spin up-conversion from nonradiative triplet states to radiative singlet states while maintaining high radiative decay rates, of >106 decays per s. These mols. harness both singlet and triplet excitons for light emission through fluorescence decay channels, leading to an intrinsic fluorescence efficiency >90% and a very high external electroluminescence efficiency, of >19%, which is comparable to that achieved in high-efficiency phosphorescence-based OLEDs.

Organic light-emitting diodes utilizing thermally activated delayed fluorescence is a potential solution for achieving stable blue devices. Sky-blue devices (CIEy < 0.4) with high stability and high external quantum efficiency (>15%) at 1000 cd m(-2) based on either delayed fluorescence or phosphorescence are still limited and very hard to achieve simultaneously. Here, we report the design and synthesis of a new thermally activated delayed fluorescence emitter, 3Ph2CzCzBN. A sky-blue device based on 3Ph2CzCzBN exhibits a high external quantum efficiency of 16.6% at 1000 cd m(-2). The device shows a sky-blue electroluminescence of 482 nm and achieves Commission Internationale de l' Eclairage coordinates of (0.17, 0.36). The sky-blue device exhibits a superb LT90 of 38 h. This is the first demonstration of high-efficiency and stable sky-blue devices (CIEy < 0.4) based on delayed fluorescence, which represents an important advance in the field of blue organic light-emitting diode technology.

Org. light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) based on thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) materials are promising for the realization of highly efficient light emitters. However, such devices have so far suffered from efficiency roll-off at high luminance. Here, we report the design and synthesis of two diboron-based mols., CzDBA and tBuCzDBA, which show excellent TADF properties and yield efficient OLEDs with very low efficiency roll-off. These donor-acceptor-donor (D-A-D) type and rod-like compds. concurrently generate TADF with a photoluminescence quantum yield of ∼100% and an 84% horizontal dipole ratio in the thin film. A green OLED based on CzDBA exhibits a high external quantum efficiency of 37.8 ± 0.6%, a current efficiency of 139.6 ± 2.8 cd A-1 and a power efficiency of 121.6 ± 3.1 lm W-1 with an efficiency roll-off of only 0.3% at 1,000 cd m-2. The device has a peak emission wavelength of 528 nm and color coordinates of the Commission International de l'Eclairage (CIE) of (0.31, 0.61), making it attractive for color-display applications.

The characteristics of the electronic excited states and the charge-transfer processes at org.-org. interfaces play an important role in org. electronic devices. However, charge-transfer excitations have proven challenging to describe with conventional d. functional theory (DFT) methodologies due to the local nature of the exchange-correlation potentials often employed. Here, we examine the excited states of model pentacene-C60 complexes using time-dependent DFT with, on one hand, one of the most popular std. hybrid functionals (B3LYP) and, on the other hand, several long-range cor. hybrid functionals for which we consider both default and nonempirically tuned range-sepn. parameters. The DFT results based on the tuned functionals are found to agree well with the available exptl. data. The results also underline that the interface geometry of the complex has a strong effect on the energies and ordering of the singlet and triplet charge-transfer states.

Functional dependence of excitation energy has been investigated for pentacene/C60 model complex in the time-dependent long-range cor. (LC) d. functional theory (TD-DFT). We esp. evaluate the performance of nonempirically tuned LC-DFT, in which the range-sepg. parameter is optimized so as to satisfy the exact condition of DFT. In addn., the effect of short-range Hartree-Fock (HF) exchange term is also examd. based on the Coulomb-attenuating method (CAM). We have shown that the nonempirical tuning scheme improves the excitation energies by the LC-DFT (LC-BLYP, LC-ωPBE, and ωB97), as well as by the CAM-DFT (CAM-BLYP, CAM-ωPBE, and CAM-ωB97), independent of the existence of short-range HF exchange term. We have also found that the functional dependence of excitation energy is very small when the nonempirically tuned parameter is applied. This indicates that the tuning of the range-sepg. parameter is essential for improving the excitation energy within the framework of the TD-LC-DFT.

CONSPECTUS: Density functional theory (DFT) and its time-dependent extension (TD-DFT) are powerful tools enabling the theoretical prediction of the ground- and excited-state properties of organic electronic materials with reasonable accuracy at affordable computational costs. Due to their excellent accuracy-to-numerical-costs ratio, semilocal and global hybrid functionals such as B3LYP have become the workhorse for geometry optimizations and the prediction of vibrational spectra in modern theoretical organic chemistry. Despite the overwhelming success of these out-of-the-box functionals for such applications, the computational treatment of electronic and structural properties that are of particular interest in organic electronic materials sometimes reveals severe and qualitative failures of such functionals. Important examples include the overestimation of conjugation, torsional barriers, and electronic coupling as well as the underestimation of bond-length alternations or excited-state energies in low-band-gap polymers. In this Account, we highlight how these failures can be traced back to the delocalization error inherent to semilocal and global hybrid functionals, which leads to the spurious delocalization of electron densities and an overestimation of conjugation. The delocalization error for systems and functionals of interest can be quantified by allowing for fractional occupation of the highest occupied molecular orbital. It can be minimized by using long-range corrected hybrid functionals and a nonempirical tuning procedure for the range-separation parameter. We then review the benefits and drawbacks of using tuned long-range corrected hybrid functionals for the description of the ground and excited states of π-conjugated systems. In particular, we show that this approach provides for robust and efficient means of characterizing the electronic couplings in organic mixed-valence systems, for the calculation of accurate torsional barriers at the polymer limit, and for the reliable prediction of the optical absorption spectrum of low-band-gap polymers. We also explain why the use of standard, out-of-the-box range-separation parameters is not recommended for the DFT and/or TD-DFT description of the ground and excited states of extended, pi-conjugated systems. Finally, we highlight a severe drawback of tuned range-separated hybrid functionals by discussing the example of the calculation of bond-length alternation in polyacetylene, which leads us to point out the challenges for future developments in this field.

The description of charge transfer excitations has long been a challenge to time dependent d. functional theory. The recently developed concept of "optimally tuned range sepd. hybrid (OT-RSH) functionals" has proven to describe charge transfer excitations accurately in many cases. However, describing solvated or embedded systems is yet a challenge. This challenge is not only computational but also conceptual, because the tuning requires identifying a specific orbital, typically the highest occupied one of the mol. under study. For solvated mols., this orbital may be delocalized over the solvent. We here demonstrate that one way of overcoming this problem is to use a locally projected SCF diagonalization on an absolutely localized MO expansion. We employ this approach to det. ionization energies and the optical gap of solvated oligothiophenes, i.e., paradigm low gap systems that are of relevance in org. electronics. Dioxane solvent mols. are explicitly represented in our calcns., and the ambiguities of straightforward parameter tuning in soln. are elucidated. We show that a consistent est. of the optimal range sepd. parameter (ω) at the limit of bulk solvation can be obtained by gradually extending the solvated system. In particular, ω is influenced by the solvent beyond the first coordination sphere. For detg. ionization energies, a considerable no. of solvent mols. on the first solvation shell must be taken into account. We demonstrate that accurately calcg. optical gaps of solvated systems using OT-RSH can be done in three steps: (i) including the chem. environment when detg. the range-sepn. parameter, (ii) taking into account the screening due to the solvent, and (iii) using realistic mol. geometries. Charge transfer excitations play a prominent role in the fields of mol. electronics and light harvesting. At the same time they have developed a reputation for being hard to predict with time-dependent d. functional theory, which is the otherwise predominant method for calcg. mol. structure and excitations. Recently, range-sepd. hybrid functionals, in particular with an optimally tuned range sepn. parameter, describe charge-transfer excitations reliably for different mols. Many of these studies focused on mols. in vacuum. Here the authors study the influence of solvation on the electronic excitations of thiophene oligomers, i.e., paradigm low gap systems. The authors take into account bulk solvation using a continuum solvation model and geometrical distortions from mol. dynamics. Three main findings emerge. First, geometrical distortions increase absorption energies by ∼0.5 eV for the longer thiophene oligomers. Second, combining optimal tuning of the range sepn. parameter with a continuum solvation method is not straightforward and has to be approached with great care. Third, optimally tuned range-sepd. hybrids without a short-range exchange component tend to inherit undesirable characteristics of semi-local functionals: with increasing system size the range sepn. parameter takes a smaller value, leading to a functional of effectively more semi-local nature and thus not accurately capturing, e.g., the satn. of the optical gap with increasing system size. We show that fundamental gaps and optical spectra of mol. solids can be predicted quant. and nonempirically within the framework of time-dependent d. functional theory (TDDFT) using the recently developed optimally tuned screened range-sepd. hybrid (OT-SRSH) functional approach. In this scheme, the electronic structure of the gas-phase mol. is detd. by optimal tuning of the range-sepn. parameter in a range-sepd. hybrid functional. Screening and polarization in the solid state are taken into account by adding long-range dielec. screening to the functional form, with the modified functional used to perform self-consistent periodic-boundary calcns. for the cryst. solid. We provide a comprehensive benchmark for the accuracy of our approach by considering the X23 set of mol. solids and comparing results obtained from TDDFT with those obtained from many-body perturbation theory in the GW-BSE approxn. We addnl. compare results obtained from dielec. screening computed within the RPA to those obtained from the computationally more efficient many-body dispersion approach and find that this influences the fundamental gap but has little effect on the optical spectra. Our approach is therefore robust and can be used for studies of mol. solids that are typically beyond the reach of computationally more intensive methods.

We present band structure and optical absorption spectra obtained from d. functional theory (DFT) and linear response time-dependent DFT (TDDFT) calcns. using a screened range-sepd. hybrid (SRSH) functional, including spin-orbit coupling, for seven prototypical semiconductors. The results are compared to those obtained from highly converged many-body perturbation theory calcns. using the GW approxn. and the GW plus Bethe-Salpeter equation (GW-BSE) approaches. We use a single empirical parameter for our SRSH calcns., fit such that the SRSH band gap reproduces the GW band gap at the Γ point. We then find that ground-state generalized Kohn-Sham SRSH eigenvalues accurately reproduce the band structure obtained from GW calcns., typically to within 0.1-0.2 eV, and optical absorption spectra obtained using TDDFT with the SRSH functional agree well with those of GW-BSE, with a mean deviation of 0.03 and 0.11 eV for the location of the first and second absorption peaks, resp., at a fraction of the computational cost.

Screened range-sepd. hybrid (SRSH) functionals are of potential interest as a computationally inexpensive yet accurate alternative approach for studying (opto)electronic properties in the solid state. At present, SRSH functionals are typically tuned to reproduce with high accuracy the properties of either bulk or low-dimensional structures, rendering such functionals not only material specific, but also structure specific. The transferability of tuned SRSH functionals between bulk and low-dimensional phases has not been examd. systematically and is desirable for straightforward and consistent modeling of size effects in nanostructures. We present a simple yet effective approach for simultaneous tuning of the fraction of short-range exact exchange and the range-sepn. parameter, which delivers accurate and transferable SRSH functionals for two-dimensional and bulk phases of two prototypical layered materials, molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) and hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN). The ground-state SRSH band structures, resulting from minimal fitting of the SRSH to a single quasiparticle energy, are found to be in excellent agreement with GW calcns. over the entire Brillouin zone. Excited-state properties are predicted using time-dependent d. functional theory calcns., based on the SRSH (TD-SRSH) functional. Calcd. absorption spectra are found to be in excellent agreement with GW and Bethe-Salpeter equation (BSE) calcns. for MoS2, but less so for h-BN; the failure of the TD-SRSH for the latter material is examd. and a BSE approach based on the SRSH ground state is shown to restore accuracy.

Thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) relies on the presence of a very small energy gap, ΔEST, between the lowest singlet and triplet excited states. ΔEST is thus a key factor in the mol. design of more efficient materials. However, its accurate theor. estn. remains challenging, esp. in the solid state due to the influence of polarization effects. The authors have quant. studied ΔEST as a function of dielec. const., ε, for four representative org. mols. using the methodol. The authors recently proposed at the Tamm-Dancoff approxn. ωB97X level of theory, where the range-sepn. parameter ω is optimized with the polarizable continuum model. The results are in very good agreement with exptl. data. Importantly, the polarization effects can lead to a marked redn. in the ΔEST value, which is favorable for TADF applications. This ΔEST decrease in the solid state is related to the hybrid characters of the lowest singlet and triplet excited states, whose dominant contribution switches to charge-transfer-like with increasing ε. The present work provides a theor. understanding on the influence of polarization effect on the singlet-triplet gap and confirms the authors' methodol. to be a reliable tool for the prediction and development of novel TADF materials.

Both the mol. orientation and conformation of thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) emitter mols. that are doped in the host matrix are crucial to det. the performance of TADF-based org. light-emitting diodes (OLEDs). However, the amorphous mol. packing prohibits observation of the structural details at the at. accuracy by exptl. techniques. Here, using atomistic mol. dynamics simulations, we have uncovered the deposition process and mol. arrangements of a representative donor-acceptor (D-A)-structured TADF emitter along with a host material on different model substrates. The simulated results indicate that despite the distinct characters of the substrates, the emitter mols. in all the films exhibit preferential horizontal orientation because of the "rodlike" structure; thus, the transition dipole moments (TDMs) of the lowest singlet excited state (S1) prefer a horizontal distribution. This is beneficial to achieve a high out-coupling efficiency. In addn., the torsion angles between the D and A units of the emitter mols. show a broadened distribution around 90° because of thermal fluctuation and intermol. interaction. Importantly, such torsional disorder can induce a drastic increase of both the S1 TDM and the spin-orbit coupling of S1 with the lowest triplet excited state (T1) while still keeping a small energy difference between S1 and T1, which would facilitate the S1 radiative decay and the T1 → S1 reverse intersystem crossing to obtain a high internal quantum efficiency. Our work provides an atomistic insight into the crit. role of both mol. orientation and torsional disorder in achieving high efficiency for an OLED based on the twisted D-A-structured TADF emitter.

Charge preservation is a necessary condition in population anal. However, one such constraint is not enough to solve the arbitrariness involved in the population anal. such as Hirshfeld population. This arbitrariness results in too small Hirshfeld charges and poor reproducibility of mol. dipolar moments. In this article, the preservation of the mol. dipole moment is imposed upon the Hirshfeld population anal. as another constraint to improve the original Hirshfeld charges. In the scheme each at. dipolar moment defined by the deformation d. is expanded as contributions from all atoms in the mol. The corresponding correction charges are then accumulated for each atom together with the original Hirshfeld charge as the predicted charge. All computed charges are generally larger than Hirshfeld charges, independent of basis set, and have very good electrostatic potential reproducibility and high correlation with the charges derived from the electrostatic potential fitting.

Multiwfn is a multifunctional program for wavefunction anal. Its main functions are: (1) Calcg. and visualizing real space function, such as electrostatic potential and electron localization function at point, in a line, in a plane or in a spatial scope. (2) Population anal. (3) Bond order anal. (4) Orbital compn. anal. (5) Plot d.-of-states and spectrum. (6) Topol. anal. for electron d. Some other useful utilities involved in quantum chem. studies are also provided. The built-in graph module enables the results of wavefunction anal. to be plotted directly or exported to high-quality graphic file. The program interface is very user-friendly and suitable for both research and teaching purpose. The code of Multiwfn is substantially optimized and parallelized. Its efficiency is demonstrated to be significantly higher than related programs with the same functions. Five practical examples involving a wide variety of systems and anal. methods are given to illustrate the usefulness of Multiwfn. The program is free of charge and open-source. Its precompiled file and source codes are available from http://multiwfn.codeplex.com. © 2011 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. J Comput Chem, 2011.

The rates for up-conversion intersystem crossing (UISC) from the T1 state to the S1 state are calcd. for a series of org. emitters with an emphasis on thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) materials. Both the spin-orbit coupling and the energy difference between the S1 and T1 states (ΔEST) are evaluated, at the d. functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT levels. The calcd. UISC rates and ΔEST values are in good agreement with available exptl. data. The authors' results underline that small ΔEST values and sizable spin-orbit coupling matrix elements have to be simultaneously realized to facilitate UISC and ultimately TADF. Importantly, the spatial sepn. of the highest occupied and lowest unoccupied MOs of the emitter, a widely accepted strategy for the design of TADF mols., does not necessarily lead to a sufficient redn. in ΔEST; in fact, either a significant charge-transfer (CT) contribution to the T1 state or a minimal energy difference between the local-excitation and charge-transfer triplet states is required to achieve a small ΔEST. Also, having S1 and T1 states of a different nature is found to strongly enhance spin-orbit coupling, which is consistent with the El-Sayed rule for ISC rates. Overall, the authors' results indicate that having either similar energies for the local-excitation and charge-transfer triplet states or the right balance between a substantial CT contribution to T1 and somewhat different natures of the S1 and T1 states, paves the way toward UISC enhancement and thus TADF efficiency improvement.

Elec. injected charge carriers in org. light-emitting devices (OLEDs) undergo recombination events to form singlet and triplet states in a 1:3 ratio, representing a fundamental hurdle for achieving high quantum efficiency. Dopants based on thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) have emerged as promising candidates for addressing the spin statistics issue in OLEDs. In these materials, reverse singlet-triplet intersystem crossing (rISC) becomes efficient, thereby activating luminescence pathways for weakly emissive triplet states. However, despite a growing consensus that torsional vibrations facilitate spin-orbit-coupling- (SOC-) driven ISC in these mols., there is a shortage of exptl. evidence. We use transient ESR and theory to show unambiguously that SOC interactions drive spin conversion and that ISC is a dynamic process gated by conformational fluctuations for benchmark carbazolyl-dicyanobenzene TADF emitters.

A review. Thermally-activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) emitters are primarily comprised of intramol. charge-transfer (ICT) mols. with small energy difference between the lowest singlet and triplet excited states. They lend extremely favorable electroluminescent performance to org. light-emitting diodes (OLEDs). This paper summarizes relevant issues and research efforts in the theor. prediction of singlet- and triplet-transition energies of ICT mols. via time-dependent d. functional theory (TDDFT). The successful application of the descriptor-based optimal Hartree-Fock percentage method and the optimally tuned range-sepd. functional to many TADF systems represent an interesting approach to the exact prediction of the complex excited-state mol. dynamics within TDDFT.

The thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) mechanism has recently attracted significant interest in the field of org. light-emitting diodes (OLEDs). TADF relies on the presence of a very small energy gap between the lowest singlet and triplet excited states. Here, time-dependent d. functional theory in the Tamm-Dancoff approxn. can be very successful in calcns. of the lowest singlet and triplet excitation energies and the corresponding singlet-triplet gap when using nonempirically tuned range-sepd. functionals. Such functionals provide very good ests. in 17 mols. used in TADF-based OLED devices with mean abs. deviations of 0.15 eV for the vertical singlet excitation energies and 0.09 eV [0.07 eV] for the adiabatic [vertical] singlet-triplet energy gaps as well as low relative errors and high correlation coeffs. compared to the corresponding exptl. values. They significantly outperform conventional functionals, a feature which is rationalized from the amt. of exact-exchange included and the delocalization error. The present work provides a reliable theor. tool for the prediction and development of novel TADF-based materials with low singlet-triplet energetic splittings.

Spin-flip in purely org. mol. systems is often described as a forbidden process; however, it is commonly obsd. and utilized to harvest triplet excitons in a wide variety of org. material-based applications. Although the initial and final electronic states of spin-flip between the lowest singlet and lowest triplet excited state are self-evident, the exact process and the role of intermediate states through which spin-flip occurs are still far from being comprehensively detd. Here, via exptl. photo-phys. investigations in soln. combined with first-principles quantum-mech. calcns., we show that efficient spin-flip in multiple donor-acceptor charge-transfer-type org. mol. systems involves the crit. role of an intermediate triplet excited state that corresponds to a partial mol. structure of the system. Our proposed mechanism unifies the understanding of the intersystem crossing mechanism in a wide variety of charge-transfer-type mol. systems, opening the way to greater control over spin-flip rates.

The design of org. compds. with nearly no gap between the first excited singlet (S1) and triplet (T1) states has been demonstrated to result in an efficient spin-flip transition from the T1 to S1 state, i.e., reverse intersystem crossing (RISC), and facilitate light emission as thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF). However, many TADF mols. have shown that a relatively appreciable energy difference between the S1 and T1 states (∼0.2 eV) could also result in a high RISC rate. We revealed from a comprehensive study of optical properties of TADF mols. that the formation of delocalized states is the key to efficient RISC and identified a chem. template for these materials. In addn., simple structural confinement further enhances RISC by suppressing structural relaxation in the triplet states. Our findings aid in designing advanced org. mols. with a high rate of RISC and, thus, achieving the max. theor. electroluminescence efficiency in org. light-emitting diodes.

Thermally-activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) is fluorescence arising from a reverse intersystem crossing (RISC) from the lowest triplet (T1) to the singlet excited state (S1), where these states are sepd. by a small energy gap (ΔEst), followed by a radiative transition to the ground state (S0). Rate consts. relating TADF processes in 1,2,3,5-tetrakis(carbazol-9-yl)-4,6-dicyanobenzene (4CzIPN) were detd. at 4 different solvent polarities (toluene, CH2Cl2, EtOH, and MeCN). The rate const. of RISC, kRISC, which is the most important factor for TADF, was significantly enhanced by a reduced ΔEst in more polar solvents. The smaller ΔEst was mainly attributable to a stabilization of the S1 state. This stabilization also induced a Stokes shift in fluorescence through a relatively large change of the dipole moment between S1 and S0 states (17 D). Despite of this factor, a neg. correlation was obsd. between ΔEst and efficiency of the delayed fluorescence (φd). This was ascribed to a lower intersystem crossing rate, kISC, and increased nonradiative decay from S1, knrs, in polar solvents.

We expose significant changes in the emission color of carbazole-based thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) emitters that arise from the presence of persistent dimer states in thin films and org. light-emitting diodes (OLEDs). Direct photoexcitation of this dimer state in 1,2,3,5-tetrakis(carbazol-9-yl)-4,6-dicyanobenzene (4CzIPN) reveals the significant influence of dimer species on the color purity of its photoluminescence and electroluminescence. The dimer species is sensitive to the sample prepn. method, and its enduring presence contributes to the widely reported concn.-mediated red shift in the photoluminescence and electroluminescence of evapd. thin films. This discovery has implications on the usability of these, and similar, mols. for OLEDs and explains disparate electroluminescence spectra presented in the literature for these compds. The dimerization-controlled changes obsd. in the TADF process and photoluminescence efficiency mean that careful consideration of dimer states is imperative in the design of future TADF emitters and the interpretation of previously reported studies of carbazole-based TADF materials.

In this work, a bicyclo[4.4.1]undecane scaffold is used to hold oligo(phenylene ethynylene) units in a cofacially stacked arrangement along the entire length of the conjugated units. We study the impact that the resulting strong interchain interactions have on the photophys. properties. The length of the individual oligomer branches was varied from three to five rings to investigate the effect of conjugation on the electronic properties of the stacked segments. Absorption and fluorescence spectra were recorded and compared to those of the corresponding unstacked analogs. Time-dependent d. functional theory calcns. were carried out and helped to rationalize the low-energy features present in the fluorescence spectra of the stacked systems. The calcns. indicate that the low-energy emissions are due to the presence of excimer-like states. The stronger intensity of the low-energy fluorescence band obsd. in the five-ring stacked system compared to the three-ring analog is attributed to the smaller activation barrier that separates the local intrachain state and the excimer-like state in the former compd.

The pseudo-geminal (pg) substitution pattern of [2.2]paracyclophane holds substituents on each ring directly atop one another. Such stacking of conjugated units leads to facile intramol. photochem. cycloaddns., and new electronic transitions in multi-decker stacks. We compare the spectroscopic and electronic properties of the pg compds. to those of their pp and po analogs and the corresponding isolated oligomers.

Efficient photodiodes from interpenetrating polymer networks
Halls, J. J. M.; Walsh, C. A.; Greenham, N. C.; Marseglia, E. A.; Friend, R. H.; Moratti, S. C.; Holmes, A. B.
Nature (London)
(

0028-0836

(

)
The photovoltaic effect involves the prodn. of electrons and holes in a semiconductor device under illumination, and their subsequent collection at opposite electrodes. In many inorg. semiconductors, photon absorption produces free electrons and holes directly. But in mol. semiconductors, absorption creates electron-hold pairs (excitons) which are bound at room temp., so that charge collection requires their dissocn. Exciton dissocn. is known to be efficient at interfaces between materials with different electron affinities and ionization potentials, where the electron is accepted by the material with larger electron affinity and the hole by the material with lower ionization potential. A two-layer diode structure can thus be used, in which excitons generated in either layer diffuse towards the interface between the layers. However, the exciton diffusion range is typically at least a factor of 10 smaller than the optical absorption depth, thus limiting the efficiency of charge collection. Here, the authors show that the interpenetrating network formed from a phase-segregated mixt. of two semiconducting polymers provides both the spatially distributed interfaces necessary for efficient charge photogeneration, and the means for sep. collecting the electrons and holes. Devices using thin films of these polymer mixts. show promise for large-area photodetectors.

The carrier collection efficiency (ηc) and energy conversion efficiency (ηe) of polymer photovoltaic cells were improved by blending of the semiconducting polymer with C60 or its functionalized derivs. Composite films of poly(2-methoxy-5-(2'-ethyl-hexyloxy)-1,4-phenylene vinylene) (MEH-PPV) and fullerenes exhibit ηc of about 29 percent of electrons per photon and ηe of about 2.9 percent, efficiencies that are better by more than two orders of magnitude than those that have been achieved with devices made with pure MEH-PPV. The efficient charge sepn. results from photoinduced electron transfer from the MEH-PPV (as donor) to C60 (as acceptor); the high collection efficiency results from a bi-continuous network of internal donor-acceptor heterojunctions.

Fluorescence-based org. light-emitting diodes have continued to attract interest because of their long operational lifetimes, high color purity of electroluminescence and potential to be manufd. at low cost in next-generation full-color display and lighting applications. The high performance is enabled by utilization of thermally activated delayed fluorescence mols. as assistant dopants that permit efficient transfer of all elec. generated singlet and triplet excitons from the assistant dopants to the fluorescent emitters. Recently, triplet harvesting via a thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) process has been established as a realistic route for obtaining ultimate internal electroluminescence (EL) quantum efficiency in org. light-emitting diodes (OLEDs). However, the possibility that the rather long transient lifetime of the triplet excited states would reduce operational stability due to an increased chance for unwarranted chem. reactions has been a concern. Herein, we demonstrate dual enhancement of EL efficiency and operational stability in OLEDs by employing a TADF mol. as an assistant dopant and a fluorescent mol. as an end emitter. The proper combination of assistant dopant and emitter mols. realized a "one-way" rapid Forster energy transfer of singlet excitons from TADF mols. to fluorescent emitters, reducing the no. of cycles of intersystem crossing (ISC) and reverse ISC in the TADF mols. and resulting in a significant enhancement of operational stability compared to OLEDs with a TADF mol. as the end emitter. In addn., we found that the presence of this rapid energy transfer significantly suppresses singlet-triplet annihilation. Using this finely-tuned rapid triplet-exciton upconversion scheme, OLED performance and lifetime was greatly improved.

A thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) sensitizer plays a key role in harvesting 100% excitons and transferring energy in TADF-assisted fluorescent org. light-emitting diodes (TAF-OLEDs). Despite its important roles, there have been few studies investigating how a TADF sensitizer affects the overall device performance and resonance energy transfer (RET) process in TAF-OLEDs. In this study, we investigate the effects of different parameters of sensitizers, i.e., spectra overlap and radiative const. (kr) on the device performances and RET process by developing two red emitters (OTPA-BT-CN and POZ-BT-CN) and choosing two TADF materials with similar photoluminescence spectra (4CzIPN and OSTFB). Mechanism studies reveal that kr of the sensitizer, rather than the overlap of sensitizer and fluorescent emitter, plays a more significant role in TAF-OLEDs. As a result, the device with higher kr of the sensitizer achieves a max. external quantum efficiency (EQE) of 12.4% with an emission peak of 612 nm, which is higher by 2.0-fold compared with that of a 4CzIPN-based device (6.3%).

The inherent flexibility afforded by mol. design has accelerated the development of a wide variety of org. semiconductors over the past 2 decades. In particular, great advances were made in the development of materials for org. light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), from early devices based on fluorescent mols. to those using phosphorescent mols. In OLEDs, elec. injected charge carriers recombine to form singlet and triplet excitons in a 1:3 ratio; the use of phosphorescent metal-org. complexes exploits the normally nonradiative triplet excitons and so enhances the overall electroluminescence efficiency. Here the authors report a class of metal-free org. electroluminescent mols. in which the energy gap between the singlet and triplet excited states is minimized by design, thereby promoting highly efficient spin up-conversion from nonradiative triplet states to radiative singlet states while maintaining high radiative decay rates, of >106 decays per s. These mols. harness both singlet and triplet excitons for light emission through fluorescence decay channels, leading to an intrinsic fluorescence efficiency >90% and a very high external electroluminescence efficiency, of >19%, which is comparable to that achieved in high-efficiency phosphorescence-based OLEDs.

Organic light-emitting diodes utilizing thermally activated delayed fluorescence is a potential solution for achieving stable blue devices. Sky-blue devices (CIEy < 0.4) with high stability and high external quantum efficiency (>15%) at 1000 cd m(-2) based on either delayed fluorescence or phosphorescence are still limited and very hard to achieve simultaneously. Here, we report the design and synthesis of a new thermally activated delayed fluorescence emitter, 3Ph2CzCzBN. A sky-blue device based on 3Ph2CzCzBN exhibits a high external quantum efficiency of 16.6% at 1000 cd m(-2). The device shows a sky-blue electroluminescence of 482 nm and achieves Commission Internationale de l' Eclairage coordinates of (0.17, 0.36). The sky-blue device exhibits a superb LT90 of 38 h. This is the first demonstration of high-efficiency and stable sky-blue devices (CIEy < 0.4) based on delayed fluorescence, which represents an important advance in the field of blue organic light-emitting diode technology.

Org. light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) based on thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) materials are promising for the realization of highly efficient light emitters. However, such devices have so far suffered from efficiency roll-off at high luminance. Here, we report the design and synthesis of two diboron-based mols., CzDBA and tBuCzDBA, which show excellent TADF properties and yield efficient OLEDs with very low efficiency roll-off. These donor-acceptor-donor (D-A-D) type and rod-like compds. concurrently generate TADF with a photoluminescence quantum yield of ∼100% and an 84% horizontal dipole ratio in the thin film. A green OLED based on CzDBA exhibits a high external quantum efficiency of 37.8 ± 0.6%, a current efficiency of 139.6 ± 2.8 cd A-1 and a power efficiency of 121.6 ± 3.1 lm W-1 with an efficiency roll-off of only 0.3% at 1,000 cd m-2. The device has a peak emission wavelength of 528 nm and color coordinates of the Commission International de l'Eclairage (CIE) of (0.31, 0.61), making it attractive for color-display applications.

The characteristics of the electronic excited states and the charge-transfer processes at org.-org. interfaces play an important role in org. electronic devices. However, charge-transfer excitations have proven challenging to describe with conventional d. functional theory (DFT) methodologies due to the local nature of the exchange-correlation potentials often employed. Here, we examine the excited states of model pentacene-C60 complexes using time-dependent DFT with, on one hand, one of the most popular std. hybrid functionals (B3LYP) and, on the other hand, several long-range cor. hybrid functionals for which we consider both default and nonempirically tuned range-sepn. parameters. The DFT results based on the tuned functionals are found to agree well with the available exptl. data. The results also underline that the interface geometry of the complex has a strong effect on the energies and ordering of the singlet and triplet charge-transfer states.

Functional dependence of excitation energy has been investigated for pentacene/C60 model complex in the time-dependent long-range cor. (LC) d. functional theory (TD-DFT). We esp. evaluate the performance of nonempirically tuned LC-DFT, in which the range-sepg. parameter is optimized so as to satisfy the exact condition of DFT. In addn., the effect of short-range Hartree-Fock (HF) exchange term is also examd. based on the Coulomb-attenuating method (CAM). We have shown that the nonempirical tuning scheme improves the excitation energies by the LC-DFT (LC-BLYP, LC-ωPBE, and ωB97), as well as by the CAM-DFT (CAM-BLYP, CAM-ωPBE, and CAM-ωB97), independent of the existence of short-range HF exchange term. This indicates that the tuning of the range-sepg. parameter is essential for improving the excitation energy within the framework of the TD-LC-DFT.

Organic electronic materials: recent advances in the DFT description of the ground and excited states using tuned range-separated hybrid functionals
Korzdorfer Thomas; Bredas Jean-Luc
Accounts of chemical research
(
2014
),
47
(
11
),
3284-91
ISSN:
.
CONSPECTUS: Density functional theory (DFT) and its time-dependent extension (TD-DFT) are powerful tools enabling the theoretical prediction of the ground- and excited-state properties of organic electronic materials with reasonable accuracy at affordable computational costs. Due to their excellent accuracy-to-numerical-costs ratio, semilocal and global hybrid functionals such as B3LYP have become the workhorse for geometry optimizations and the prediction of vibrational spectra in modern theoretical organic chemistry. Despite the overwhelming success of these out-of-the-box functionals for such applications, the computational treatment of electronic and structural properties that are of particular interest in organic electronic materials sometimes reveals severe and qualitative failures of such functionals. Important examples include the overestimation of conjugation, torsional barriers, and electronic coupling as well as the underestimation of bond-length alternations or excited-state energies in low-band-gap polymers. In this Account, we highlight how these failures can be traced back to the delocalization error inherent to semilocal and global hybrid functionals, which leads to the spurious delocalization of electron densities and an overestimation of conjugation. The delocalization error for systems and functionals of interest can be quantified by allowing for fractional occupation of the highest occupied molecular orbital. It can be minimized by using long-range corrected hybrid functionals and a nonempirical tuning procedure for the range-separation parameter. We then review the benefits and drawbacks of using tuned long-range corrected hybrid functionals for the description of the ground and excited states of π-conjugated systems. In particular, we show that this approach provides for robust and efficient means of characterizing the electronic couplings in organic mixed-valence systems, for the calculation of accurate torsional barriers at the polymer limit, and for the reliable prediction of the optical absorption spectrum of low-band-gap polymers. We also explain why the use of standard, out-of-the-box range-separation parameters is not recommended for the DFT and/or TD-DFT description of the ground and excited states of extended, pi-conjugated systems. Finally, we highlight a severe drawback of tuned range-separated hybrid functionals by discussing the example of the calculation of bond-length alternation in polyacetylene, which leads us to point out the challenges for future developments in this field.

The description of charge transfer excitations has long been a challenge to time dependent d. functional theory. The recently developed concept of "optimally tuned range sepd. hybrid (OT-RSH) functionals" has proven to describe charge transfer excitations accurately in many cases. However, describing solvated or embedded systems is yet a challenge. This challenge is not only computational but also conceptual, because the tuning requires identifying a specific orbital, typically the highest occupied one of the mol. under study. For solvated mols., this orbital may be delocalized over the solvent. We here demonstrate that one way of overcoming this problem is to use a locally projected SCF diagonalization on an absolutely localized MO expansion. We employ this approach to det. ionization energies and the optical gap of solvated oligothiophenes, i.e., paradigm low gap systems that are of relevance in org. electronics. Dioxane solvent mols. are explicitly represented in our calcns., and the ambiguities of straightforward parameter tuning in soln. are elucidated. We show that a consistent est. of the optimal range sepd. parameter (ω) at the limit of bulk solvation can be obtained by gradually extending the solvated system. In particular, ω is influenced by the solvent beyond the first coordination sphere. For detg. ionization energies, a considerable no. of solvent mols. on the first solvation shell must be taken into account. We demonstrate that accurately calcg. optical gaps of solvated systems using OT-RSH can be done in three steps: (i) including the chem. environment when detg. the range-sepn. parameter, (ii) taking into account the screening due to the solvent, and (iii) using realistic mol. geometries. D. functional theory (DFT) approaches based on range-sepd. hybrid functionals are currently methods of choice for the description of the charge-transfer (CT) states in org. donor/acceptor solar cells. However, these calcns. are usually performed on small-size donor/acceptor complexes and as result do not account for electronic polarization effects. Here, using a pentacene/C60 complex as a model system, we discuss the ability of long-range cor. (LCR) hybrid functionals in combination with the polarizable continuum model (PCM) to det. the impact of the solid-state environment on the CT states. The CT energies are found to be insensitive to the interactions with the dielec. medium when a conventional time-dependent DFT/PCM (TDDFT/PCM) approach is used. However, a decrease in the energy of the CT state in the framework of LRC functionals can be obtained by using a smaller range-sepd. parameter when going from an isolated donor/acceptor complex to the solid-state case.
